page.title: 12The Wildlife of Shoreham
page.content: A very distinctive feature of Lancing's landscape is an area of inland water behind the beach, called Widewater. The area is to the west of Shoreham. It is a shallow lagoon parted from the sea by a low shingle bank and covers an area of around 7.5 hectares with a 1 metre depth. The bottom of Widewater is a very soft mud with a high organic content . During the summer months the lagoon is covered by a large mat of green algae. The local history of Widewater dates back as far as the eleventh century when it tells of an estuary of the River Adur covering the area where Shoreham Airport now stands. There is another dating about 1250 when a shore drift of shingle was built up to spilt the estuary from the sea.By 1700 streams to west of the River Adur had been cut off.
